quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Thermal Calculations
quiz.subtitle: Unit 7, Quiz 5: Heat Capacity and Calorimetry
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: How much energy is required to raise the temperature of 2.0 kg of water from 20°C to 50°C? (Specific heat of water = 4184 J/kg·°C)
An aluminum block has a mass of 0.5 kg and a specific heat of 900 J/kg·°C. What is the Heat Capacity (C) of this specific block?
questions.explanation: Heat Capacity (C) is calculated as C = mc. Here, C = (0.5 kg)(900 J/kg·°C) = 450 J/°C. Note that Heat Capacity does not include the mass unit in its result.

questions.question: If 100g of water at 80°C is mixed with 100g of water at 20°C in an insulated container, what will be the final equilibrium temperature?
questions.explanation: When equal masses of the same substance are mixed, the final temperature is the simple average: (80 + 20) / 2 = 50°C. Energy lost by hot water equals energy gained by cold water.

questions.question: A 500g piece of copper (c = 385 J/kg·°C) loses 7700 J of energy. By how much did its temperature decrease?
questions.explanation: Convert mass to kg: 0.5 kg. Use ΔT = Q / (mc). ΔT = 7700 / (0.5 * 385) = 7700 / 192.5 = 40°C.

questions.question: In a calorimetry experiment, the 'Method of Mixtures' relies on which fundamental physics principle?
questions.explanation: The assumption that heat lost by the hot object equals heat gained by the cold object (Q_out = Q_in) is a direct application of energy conservation.

questions.question: 2.0 kg of water at 90°C is mixed with 1.0 kg of water at 30°C. What is the final temperature of the mixture?
Which requires more heat: raising 1 kg of water (c = 4184 J/kg·°C) by 10°C or raising 10 kg of iron (c = 450 J/kg·°C) by 10°C?
options: They require the same amount of heat.
It depends on the starting temperature.
questions.explanation: For water: Q = (1)(4184)(10) = 41,840 J. For iron: Q = (10)(450)(10) = 45,000 J. The iron requires slightly more.

questions.question: A 0.2 kg metal sample at 100°C is placed in 0.1 kg of water at 20°C. The final temperature is 40°C. What is the specific heat of the metal?
questions.explanation: Heat gained by water = (0.1)(4184)(40-20) = 8368 J. Heat lost by metal = (0.2)(c_metal)(100-40) = 12(c_metal). Set equal: 12c = 8368 -> c ≈ 697 J/kg·°C.

questions.question: If you double the heat input (Q) to a sample while keeping the mass constant, what happens to the temperature change (ΔT)?
questions.explanation: Since Q = mcΔT, Q and ΔT are directly proportional. If Q doubles, ΔT must also double.

questions.question: Why is the final temperature of a mix of 1kg oil (c = 2000 J/kg·°C) and 1kg water (c = 4184 J/kg·°C) NOT the simple average of their starting temperatures?
options: Because they have different specific heat capacities.
Because oil does not absorb heat.
Because the container absorbs all the energy.
questions.explanation: The simple average only works if the Heat Capacities (mc) are equal. Because water has a higher specific heat, it resists temperature change more, pulling the final temperature closer to water's initial temperature.
